repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Closes #20857, #20246 (?)

<s>Not fully ready, but I'm publishing it early because I want to start getting some reviews.</s> Should be ready now!

Missing things/questions:
- [x] <s>Make sure `K` and `gx` work (refer to [this implementation](https://github.com/folke/noice.nvim/blob/74c2902146b080035beb19944baf6f014a954720/lua/noice/text/markdown.lua#L212)).</s> See the concealing debate below.
- [x] <s>Not long ago I made [this change](https://github.com/folke/noice.nvim/pull/571) in `noice` to always parse injections. @lewis6991 what do you think about that? Is there a better way to do this here?</s> It's okay since these buffers are small.
- [x] <s>Not sure what [this comment](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/d21f82feb56a1661a63b3f552d5302bdf6bdc280/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/util.lua#L1452-L1453) means/if we should care about it. @folke we would appreciate your wisdom here.</s> Seems like using `vim.treesitter.get_parser()` is fine.
- [ ] Fix small "flashing" between the lines being set on the buffer and the highlights being applied.

comment_data.body: You shouldn't need to cache the queries since they are already cached via a weak table in `vim.treesitter.query`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1290,18 +1290,169 @@ function M._trim(contents, opts)
   return contents
 end
 
---- Generates a table mapping markdown code block lang to vim syntax,
---- based on g:markdown_fenced_languages
----@return table table of lang -> syntax mappings
-local function get_markdown_fences()
-  local fences = {}
-  for _, fence in pairs(vim.g.markdown_fenced_languages or {}) do
-    local lang, syntax = fence:match('^(.*)=(.*)$')
-    if lang then
-      fences[lang] = syntax
-    end
-  end
-  return fences
+---@alias MarkdownBlock {line:string}
+---@alias MarkdownCodeBlock {code:string[], lang:string}
+---@alias Markdown (MarkdownBlock|MarkdownCodeBlock)[]
+
+---@param text string
+---@param opts? {ft?: string}
+---@return Markdown
+local function parse_markdown(text, opts)
+  opts = opts or {}
+  text = text:gsub('</?pre>', '```'):gsub('\r', '')
+
+  -- Replace common HTML entities.
+  local entities =
+    { nbsp = '', lt = '<', gt = '>', amp = '&', quot = '"', apos = "'", ensp = ' ', emsp = ' ' }
+  for entity, char in pairs(entities) do
+    text = text:gsub('&' .. entity .. ';', char)
+  end
+
+  local ret = {} ---@type Markdown
+  local lines = vim.split(text, '\n')
+  local l = 1
+
+  local function is_empty(line)
+    return line and line:find('^%s*$')
+  end
+
+  local function eat_nl()
+    while is_empty(lines[l + 1]) do
+      l = l + 1
+    end
+  end
+
+  local function is_rule(line)
+    return line and line:find('^%s*[%*%-_][%*%-_][%*%-_]+%s*$')
+  end
+
+  local function is_code_block(line)
+    return line and line:find('^%s*```')
+  end
+
+  while l <= #lines do
+    local line = lines[l]
+    if is_empty(line) then
+      local is_start = l == 1
+      eat_nl()
+      local is_end = l == #lines
+      if not (is_code_block(lines[l + 1]) or is_rule(lines[l + 1]) or is_start or is_end) then
+        table.insert(ret, { line = '' })
+      end
+    elseif is_code_block(line) then
+      local lang = line:match('```%s*(%S+)') or opts.ft or 'text'
+      local block = { lang = lang, code = {} }
+      while lines[l + 1] and not is_code_block(lines[l + 1]) do
+        table.insert(block.code, lines[l + 1])
+        l = l + 1
+      end
+
+      local prev = ret[#ret]
+      if prev and not is_rule(prev.line) then
+        table.insert(ret, { line = '' })
+      end
+
+      table.insert(ret, block)
+      l = l + 1
+      eat_nl()
+    elseif is_rule(line) then
+      table.insert(ret, { line = '---' })
+      eat_nl()
+    else
+      local prev = ret[#ret]
+      if prev and prev.code then
+        table.insert(ret, { line = '' })
+      end
+      table.insert(ret, { line = line })
+    end
+    l = l + 1
+  end
+
+  return ret
+end
+
+---@type table<string, Query?>
+local ts_queries = {}

comment_data.body:
It probably means do not use the parser in vim.treesitter.highlighter.

I don't think we should use `LanguageTree.new` for this. Instead we should use `vim.treesitter.get_parser()`.

```suggestion
  local function eat_nl(l)

      l = l + 1
    end
    return l
  end
```

Then at the call site you'd use:

```lua
l = eat_nl(l)
```

comment_regular_data.body: also cheeky preview of how this looks ;) **_Before_**: **_After_**:
We probably still want to display url's in `[text](url)` nodes so TUI users to click on the links.

> We probably still want to display url's in `[text](url)` nodes so TUI users to click on the links.

Ew  . Let's make `gx` (and mouse-click) smarter instead of just suffering. Can assign that to me to avoid blocking this PR.

I have my terminal setup to open links with `<shift><left-click>` which works with everything, I don't want another thing I need to remember.

If we must not have the links shown then we would need to rely on some terminal extension to do this for us.

> suffering

> If we must not have the links shown then we would need to rely on some terminal extension to do this for us.

There is such a thing: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/11871

> We probably still want to display url's in `[text](url)` nodes so TUI users to click on the links.

Yes please. I don't want links concealed by default either. But we can use `conceal` for this, just like the Markdown filetype plugin does already, so that users can make that choice for themselves.

> We probably still want to display url's in `[text](url)` nodes so TUI users to click on the links.

Yes, it is also very handy with terminal URL hinting

Regarding the `[text](url)` thing:

Keep in mind that `url` is not limited to `http(s)`, but it can contain `file:///` or any other scheme as well. It's used by language servers to refer to classes or functions either in the same project, or in a dependency. If we hide the url, it would be good to have a way to follow those (also in the editor)

>  just like the Markdown filetype plugin does already

Or the treesitter queries for Markdown. We do not have to use the bundled ones as-is and can make our own choices about `conceal`.

About concealing: Shouldn't [these settings](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/65738202f8be3ca63b75197d48f2c7a9324c035b/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/util.lua#L1701-L1702) result in links always being concealed?

> About concealing: Shouldn't [these settings](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/65738202f8be3ca63b75197d48f2c7a9324c035b/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/util.lua#L1701-L1702) result in links always being concealed?

Yes they should, though I don't think those settings should be set unconditionally. `nvim_get_option_value` now supports getting an option for a filetype, so we should get the values for `'conceallevel'` and `'concealcursor'` for Markdown filetypes and use those values.

> Yes they should, though I don't think those settings should be set unconditionally. nvim_get_option_value now supports getting an option for a filetype, so we should get the values for 'conceallevel' and 'concealcursor' for Markdown filetypes and use those values.

@gpanders Sounds good. I've modified them to use `nvim_get_option_value`.

I need some help: I've noticed that there's a small "flash" between the lines being set on the buffer and before the highlights are applied (it would help if interested parties try out this branch to understand what I mean). Although it's hardly noticeable, how could I prevent that?

> I need some help: I've noticed that there's a small "flash" between the lines being set on the buffer and before the highlights are applied (it would help if interested parties try out this branch to understand what I mean). Although it's hardly noticeable, how could I prevent that? I haven't been able to reproduce this, but I did see something else when testing. With `clangd` in a C source file, I'm seeing new `` tags that aren't there on master: **master**: **PR**: Neither case has any highlighting. Not sure why.

> I haven't been able to reproduce this, but I did see something else when testing. Yeah, it's hardly noticeable and you have to really squint to notice it. > With clangd in a C source file, I'm seeing new tags that aren't there on master: @gpanders It seems like this is related to https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/25073#discussion_r1321606162. I'll investigate this. @gpanders Hmmm I'm not able to reproduce this: What do you have set for `conceallevel`? And which C Treesitter parser are you using? The one bundled in Neovim, or the one from `nvim-treesitter`?

> > We probably still want to display url's in `[text](url)` nodes so TUI users to click on the links.
> 
> Yes please. I don't want links concealed by default either. But we can use `conceal` for this, just like the Markdown filetype plugin does already, so that users can make that choice for themselves.

I have not changed my stance on URL's specifically, but for other tokens I've come around to enabling conceal by default for the hover window specifically. I typically do not enable conceal on Markdown files at all because I want to see the _exact_ text I'm editing, the presentation of the text is secondary. However, in the hover window the situation is reversed: the text is not being edited, the presentation is the primary focus, so concealing syntax tokens (e.g. `*`, `_`, `` ` ``, etc.) makes more sense.

Unfortunately I don't know of a way to conceal these tokens without also concealing URLs, not without modifications to the Markdown parser (which I am not advocating). But unsetting `'concealcursor'` at least would show the URLs when the cursor is over them.
